awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: A New Theory of 3D Particle Characterization
awd_abstract_narration:
Granular materials such as soils are prevalent in nature and broadly used as engineering materials for civil infrastructure (e.g., in dams, levees, roads and railways). 3D particle geometry is a key piece of information to fundamentally understand the granular material behavior subjected to static and dynamic loadings.  While the 3D particle geometry is characterized in terms of four features, i.e., volume, surface area, size and shape, the characteristics of the 3D geometry can only be fully understood through the interrelationships of these four features. For example, there is limited understanding of how volume is related to surface area for random mineral particles. This relationship clearly depends on the particle shape as well (e.g., a sphere and an ellipsoid with the same volume have different surface areas). The relationship between these features is therefore key to comprehensively address the four-dimensional aspects of 3D particle geometry, which will enable the fundamental understanding of their combined influence on the behavior of granular materials and will help to better design civil infrastructure against natural hazards such as earthquakes. In addition, this project will develop educational modules for undergraduate classes by closely integrating with the research activities and by using recent advances in 3D printing and scanning technologies. The research team will incorporate the education modules into existing undergraduate level courses in geotechnical and materials engineering. This educational effort will provide a new model for successfully integrating knowledge discovery, teaching and learning in the area of granular materials.

This project will develop a new theory for comprehensive 3D particle geometry characterization based on a new, simple formula that correlates the parameters defining the 3D particle geometry. This formula unravels the intertwined relationships between the four particle geometry parameters by expressing the 3D particle morphology as a function of surface area, volume and size. The study develops three research hypotheses to test the new theory step-by-step. The research will (i) characterize individual particles using the researched formula, (ii) characterize particle groups (i.e., granular material) in association with a power law relationship between the surface area and volume, and (iii) perform testing to investigate the relationship between the characterized geometric information using the new approach and various mechanical properties of granular materials, including dilatancy and strength.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
3D particle geometry is an important particle-scale property that significantly influences the macroscopic behavior of granular materials. For example, track ballast, essential for railroad infrastructure, plays a critical role in facilitating drainage around the tracks and distributing the load from train traffic. The geometry of these ballast particles is a key factor affecting their function. There are four distinct attributes of a 3D particle geometry (ℊ) - volume, surface area, size, and shape - traditionally considered separately in the research community to study their influences on the behavior of granular materials, such as shape effect or size effect.

A major outcome of this project is the development of a robust theoretical basis that integrates all 3D geometric attributes into a unified model. The formulation posits that particle geometry is a function of the surface-area-to-volume ratio (A/V), represented as ℊ = (A/V)k x V. Here, the k is a set of indices {0,1,2,3}, each linking ℊ to different geometric attributes - volume (V), surface area (A), size (Ď), and shape (β), respectively - with variations only in the exponent k.

The surface-area-to-volume ratio (A/V), also known as specific surface, is a critical particle-scale parameter that influences various properties and behaviors of granular materials, including modulus, strength, permeability, and transport processes. A major outcome of this project is that it unifies traditionally separate analyses, such as shape or size effect, to be consolidated under the A/V effect, represented by ℊ = (A/V)k x V.

By log-transforming the equation, we get log(V) = -k x log(A/V) + log(ℊ), allowing for graphical representation in a log-log space where the x-axis denotes log(A/V) and the y-axis log(V). This framework is introduced as "particle geometry space" in this project. From the log-transformed equation, it is clear that the intercept at A/V = 1 on a line from a data point, with a slope ranging from 0 to -3, represents the logarithmic values of volume (V), surface area (A), size (Ď), and shape (β), respectively. The graphical interpretation is depicted in Figure 1a. Therefore, within the particle geometry space, all four aspects of 3D particle geometry ℊ can be comprehensively presented.

A sphere-shaped particle always aligns with the sphere line, where β = 36π, as illustrated in Figure 1b. For example, the two yellow dots on the sphere line represent spheres of different sizes. Since no shape can be more spherical than a sphere, no data points can appear in the grey-shaded area labeled as Iz (impossible zone) beneath the sphere line, with 36π representing the minimum possible value for β. Graphically, being farther from the sphere line indicates further deviation from a spherical shape.

To analyze particle populations, which consist of many particles, statistical measures can be employed to capture (i) the average shape, indicated by the average shape index β*, and (ii) the overall relationship between shape and size, characterized by the slope α, which indicates how shape varies with size. Specifically, log(β*) is derived by calculating the arithmetic mean of the log(β) values obtained from individual particles. The shape-size relationship falls into three categories: (a) Case 1 (α = -3), showing no specific relationship; (b) Case 2 (α > -3), where larger particles are more spherical; and (c) Case 3 (α < -3), where smaller particles are more spherical. These categories are represented by different slopes in the particle geometry space, as illustrated in Figure 2. Despite identical average shapes across all cases (same β*) in this specific example, variations in the slopes indicate distinct particle sets.

The distinct line formed by the data points in the log-log space reveals a phenotypic trait of the particle geometries within a particle family, influenced by their geological origins and histories that they share. This phenotypic trait, extending beyond mere shape or size characteristics, offers new insights that improve both the characterization and modeling of particle geometries for numerical simulations.

This project holds broad relevance across various disciplines - including agriculture, pharmaceuticals, geotechnical, and chemical engineering - due to the pervasive use of granular materials, which are the second-most manipulated materials in industry after water. Consequently, the insights gained from this project are poised to broadly impact these fields by transforming particle characterization methods.

Additionally, this project has generated an extensive dataset, which has been published under the Open Data Commons Attribution License, allowing anyone to freely use it. The complete dataset, available in the NSF DesignSafe-CI repository, includes 382 digital 3D particle geometry files. It is accessible via the following link: https://doi.org/10.17603/ds2-p634-pg95. This dataset is notably larger than any previously available datasets of its kind and is expected to significantly enhance research capabilities across disciplines that work with granular materials.
